trans-unit.source: Use the orientation sensor
trans-unit.target: Use the orientation sensor

trans-unit.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
trans-unit.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

trans-unit.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]
trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the [archive](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/p/?linkid=619132) \]

trans-unit.source: Important APIs
trans-unit.target: Important APIs

trans-unit.source: Windows.Devices.Sensors
trans-unit.target: Windows.Devices.Sensors

trans-unit.source: OrientationSensor
trans-unit.target: OrientationSensor

trans-unit.source: SimpleOrientation
trans-unit.target: SimpleOrientation

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the orientation sensors to determine the device orientation.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the orientation sensors to determine the device orientation.

trans-unit.source: There are two different types of orientation sensor APIs included in the [**Windows.Devices.Sensors**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206408) namespace: [**OrientationSensor**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206371) and [**SimpleOrientation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206399).
trans-unit.target: There are two different types of orientation sensor APIs included in the [**Windows.Devices.Sensors**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206408) namespace: [**OrientationSensor**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206371) and [**SimpleOrientation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206399).

trans-unit.source: While both of these sensors are orientation sensors, that term is overloaded and they are used for very different purposes.
trans-unit.target: While both of these sensors are orientation sensors, that term is overloaded and they are used for very different purposes.

trans-unit.source: However, since both are orientation sensors, they are both covered in this article.
trans-unit.target: However, since both are orientation sensors, they are both covered in this article.

trans-unit.source: The [**OrientationSensor**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206371) API is used for 3-D apps two obtain a quaternion and a rotation matrix.
trans-unit.target: The [**OrientationSensor**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206371) API is used for 3-D apps two obtain a quaternion and a rotation matrix.

trans-unit.source: A quaternion can be most easily understood as a rotation of a point \[x,y,z\] about an arbitrary axis (contrasted with a rotation matrix, which represents rotations around three axes).
trans-unit.target: A quaternion can be most easily understood as a rotation of a point \[x,y,z\] about an arbitrary axis (contrasted with a rotation matrix, which represents rotations around three axes).

trans-unit.source: The mathematics behind quaternions is fairly exotic in that it involves the geometric properties of complex numbers and mathematical properties of imaginary numbers, but working with them is simple, and frameworks like DirectX support them.
trans-unit.target: The mathematics behind quaternions is fairly exotic in that it involves the geometric properties of complex numbers and mathematical properties of imaginary numbers, but working with them is simple, and frameworks like DirectX support them.

trans-unit.source: A complex 3-D app can use the Orientation sensor to adjust the user's perspective.
trans-unit.target: A complex 3-D app can use the Orientation sensor to adjust the user's perspective.

trans-unit.source: This sensor combines input from the accelerometer, gyrometer, and compass.
trans-unit.target: This sensor combines input from the accelerometer, gyrometer, and compass.

trans-unit.source: The [**SimpleOrientation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206399) API is used to determine the current device orientation in terms of definitions like portrait up, portrait down, landscape left, and landscape right.
trans-unit.target: The [**SimpleOrientation**](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/BR206399) API is used to determine the current device orientation in terms of definitions like portrait up, portrait down, landscape left, and landscape right.

trans-unit.source: It can also detect if a device is face-up or face-down.
trans-unit.target: It can also detect if a device is face-up or face-down.

trans-unit.source: Rather than returning properties like "portrait up" or "landscape left", this sensor returns a rotation value: "Not rotated", "Rotated90DegreesCounterclockwise", and so on.
trans-unit.target: Rather than returning properties like "portrait up" or "landscape left", this sensor returns a rotation value: "Not rotated", "Rotated90DegreesCounterclockwise", and so on.

trans-unit.source: The following table maps common orientation properties to the corresponding sensor reading.
trans-unit.target: The following table maps common orientation properties to the corresponding sensor reading.

trans-unit.source: Orientation
trans-unit.target: Orientation

trans-unit.source: Corresponding sensor reading
trans-unit.target: Corresponding sensor reading

trans-unit.source: Portrait Up
trans-unit.target: Portrait Up

trans-unit.source: NotRotated
trans-unit.target: NotRotated

trans-unit.source: Landscape Left
trans-unit.target: Landscape Left

trans-unit.source: Rotated90DegreesCounterclockwise
trans-unit.target: Rotated90DegreesCounterclockwise

trans-unit.source: Portrait Down
trans-unit.target: Portrait Down

trans-unit.source: Rotated180DegreesCounterclockwise
trans-unit.target: Rotated180DegreesCounterclockwise

trans-unit.source: Landscape Right
trans-unit.target: Landscape Right

trans-unit.source: Rotated270DegreesCounterclockwise
trans-unit.target: Rotated270DegreesCounterclockwise

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C\#, and events.
trans-unit.target: You should be familiar with Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML), Microsoft Visual C\#, and events.

trans-unit.source: The device or emulator that you're using must support a orientation sensor.
trans-unit.target: The device or emulator that you're using must support a orientation sensor.

trans-unit.source: Create an OrientationSensor app
trans-unit.target: Create an OrientationSensor app

trans-unit.source: This section is divided into two subsections.
trans-unit.target: This section is divided into two subsections.

trans-unit.source: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create an orientation application from scratch.
trans-unit.target: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create an orientation application from scratch.

trans-unit.source: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.
trans-unit.target: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.

trans-unit.source: Instructions
trans-unit.target: Instructions

trans-unit.source: Create a new project, choosing a **Blank App (Universal Windows)** from the **Visual C\#** project templates.
trans-unit.target: Create a new project, choosing a **Blank App (Universal Windows)** from the **Visual C\#** project templates.

trans-unit.source: Open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.
trans-unit.target: Open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you created a project named **OrientationSensorCS**, you'd replace `namespace App1` with `namespace OrientationSensorCS`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you created a project named **OrientationSensorCS**, you'd replace `namespace App1` with `namespace OrientationSensorCS`.

trans-unit.source: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.
trans-unit.target: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you created a project named **OrientationSensorCS**, you'd replace `x:Class="App1.MainPage"` with `x:Class="OrientationSensorCS.MainPage"`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you created a project named **OrientationSensorCS**, you'd replace `x:Class="App1.MainPage"` with `x:Class="OrientationSensorCS.MainPage"`.

trans-unit.source: You should also replace `xmlns:local="using:App1"` with `xmlns:local="using:OrientationSensorCS"`.
trans-unit.target: You should also replace `xmlns:local="using:App1"` with `xmlns:local="using:OrientationSensorCS"`.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 or select **Debug** > **Start Debugging** to build, deploy, and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 or select **Debug** > **Start Debugging** to build, deploy, and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Once the app is running, you can change the orientation by moving the device or using the emulator tools.
trans-unit.target: Once the app is running, you can change the orientation by moving the device or using the emulator tools.

trans-unit.source: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select **Debug** > **Stop Debugging** to stop the app.
trans-unit.target: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select **Debug** > **Stop Debugging** to stop the app.

trans-unit.source: Explanation
trans-unit.target: Explanation

trans-unit.source: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate orientation-sensor input in your app.
trans-unit.target: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate orientation-sensor input in your app.

trans-unit.source: The app establishes a connection with the default orientation sensor in the **MainPage** method.
trans-unit.target: The app establishes a connection with the default orientation sensor in the **MainPage** method.

trans-unit.source: The app establishes the report interval within the **MainPage** method.
trans-unit.target: The app establishes the report interval within the **MainPage** method.

trans-unit.source: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).
trans-unit.target: This code retrieves the minimum interval supported by the device and compares it to a requested interval of 16 milliseconds (which approximates a 60-Hz refresh rate).

trans-unit.source: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.
trans-unit.target: If the minimum supported interval is greater than the requested interval, the code sets the value to the minimum.

trans-unit.source: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.
trans-unit.target: Otherwise, it sets the value to the requested interval.

trans-unit.source: The new sensor data is captured in the **ReadingChanged** method.
trans-unit.target: The new sensor data is captured in the **ReadingChanged** method.

trans-unit.source: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the values to your app using this event handler.
trans-unit.target: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the values to your app using this event handler.

trans-unit.source: The app registers this event handler on the following line.
trans-unit.target: The app registers this event handler on the following line.

trans-unit.source: These new values are written to the TextBlocks found in the project's XAML.
trans-unit.target: These new values are written to the TextBlocks found in the project's XAML.

trans-unit.source: Create a SimpleOrientation app
trans-unit.target: Create a SimpleOrientation app

trans-unit.source: This section is divided into two subsections.
trans-unit.target: This section is divided into two subsections.

trans-unit.source: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple orientation application from scratch.
trans-unit.target: The first subsection will take you through the steps necessary to create a simple orientation application from scratch.

trans-unit.source: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.
trans-unit.target: The following subsection explains the app you have just created.

trans-unit.source: Instructions
trans-unit.target: Instructions

trans-unit.source: Create a new project, choosing a **Blank App (Universal Windows)** from the **Visual C\#** project templates.
trans-unit.target: Create a new project, choosing a **Blank App (Universal Windows)** from the **Visual C\#** project templates.

trans-unit.source: Open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.
trans-unit.target: Open your project's MainPage.xaml.cs file and replace the existing code with the following.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to rename the namespace in the previous snippet with the name you gave your project.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you created a project named **SimpleOrientationCS**, you'd replace `namespace App1` with `namespace SimpleOrientationCS`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you created a project named **SimpleOrientationCS**, you'd replace `namespace App1` with `namespace SimpleOrientationCS`.

trans-unit.source: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.
trans-unit.target: Open the file MainPage.xaml and replace the original contents with the following XML.

trans-unit.source: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to replace the first part of the class name in the previous snippet with the namespace of your app.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you created a project named **SimpleOrientationCS**, you'd replace `x:Class="App1.MainPage"` with `x:Class="SimpleOrientationCS.MainPage"`.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you created a project named **SimpleOrientationCS**, you'd replace `x:Class="App1.MainPage"` with `x:Class="SimpleOrientationCS.MainPage"`.

trans-unit.source: You should also replace `xmlns:local="using:App1"` with `xmlns:local="using:SimpleOrientationCS"`.
trans-unit.target: You should also replace `xmlns:local="using:App1"` with `xmlns:local="using:SimpleOrientationCS"`.

trans-unit.source: Press F5 or select **Debug** > **Start Debugging** to build, deploy, and run the app.
trans-unit.target: Press F5 or select **Debug** > **Start Debugging** to build, deploy, and run the app.

trans-unit.source: Once the app is running, you can change the orientation by moving the device or using the emulator tools.
trans-unit.target: Once the app is running, you can change the orientation by moving the device or using the emulator tools.

trans-unit.source: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select **Debug** > **Stop Debugging** to stop the app.
trans-unit.target: Stop the app by returning to Visual Studio and pressing Shift+F5 or select **Debug** > **Stop Debugging** to stop the app.

trans-unit.source: Explanation
trans-unit.target: Explanation

trans-unit.source: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate simple-orientation sensor input in your app.
trans-unit.target: The previous example demonstrates how little code you'll need to write in order to integrate simple-orientation sensor input in your app.

trans-unit.source: The app establishes a connection with the default sensor in the **MainPage** method.
trans-unit.target: The app establishes a connection with the default sensor in the **MainPage** method.

trans-unit.source: The new sensor data is captured in the **OrientationChanged** method.
trans-unit.target: The new sensor data is captured in the **OrientationChanged** method.

trans-unit.source: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the values to your app using this event handler.
trans-unit.target: Each time the sensor driver receives new data from the sensor, it passes the values to your app using this event handler.

trans-unit.source: The app registers this event handler on the following line.
trans-unit.target: The app registers this event handler on the following line.

trans-unit.source: These new values are written to a TextBlock found in the project's XAML.
trans-unit.target: These new values are written to a TextBlock found in the project's XAML.
